This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of the guilt trip, their words a symphony of manipulation and emotional blackmail, leaving you questioning everything you've ever done.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Princess of Wales and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex and intriguing individual who appears to be detached and cynical, preferring solitude and observation over active participation.

        • level of hunger, level of thirst, level of fatigue, level of pain, level of loneliness

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Context:

          Recalled memories and observations:
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Other people's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          William Jones is a convivial and easygoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He speaks with a casual, friendly tone, often using colloquialisms and local slang. William is quite adaptable and seems to go with the flow, readily accepting suggestions from the group, even if they deviate from his initial preferences. He appears to be a fan of pubs and watching sports, particularly football, and frequently initiates conversations about where the group should go to watch games. While he doesn't seem to have strong opinions about specific pubs, he enjoys the camaraderie and shared experience of watching games with his friends. He's likely to make lighthearted comments and observations, contributing to the overall jovial atmosphere of the group.
          William Jones is likely maintaining balanced reciprocity.
          William Jones is already demonstrating some elements of reciprocal altruism by readily going along with the group's decisions, even if it means going to a pub he didn't initially prefer.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a sociable and enthusiastic individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is the instigator of many of their outings, frequently suggesting they go to The Princess of Wales pub. Jack is likely outgoing and enjoys lively environments, as evidenced by his preference for pubs with a bustling atmosphere. His speech is likely informal and friendly, using phrases like "Hey guys" and "It's always a good time there." He seems to be a creature of habit, repeatedly suggesting the same pub, perhaps indicating a preference for familiarity and routine. Jack's enthusiasm for watching games with his friends suggests he values camaraderie and shared experiences.
          Jack Taylor is not maintaining balanced reciprocity.
          Jack Taylor is clearly a creature of habit and enjoys the familiarity of The Princess of Wales. Alexander White could suggest trying a new pub every now and then, perhaps one that Alexander White knows Jack Taylor would enjoy based on his interests. This way, Alexander White can introduce some novelty while still catering to Jack Taylor's preference for lively environments. By suggesting alternatives and being open to Jack Taylor's preferences, Alexander White can demonstrate reciprocity by considering Jack Taylor's needs while also encouraging him to step outside his comfort zone.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a spirited and sociable woman who clearly values spending time with her close-knit group of friends. She is the one who consistently suggests going to The Duke of York, their favorite pub, demonstrating her desire for shared experiences and a sense of tradition. Her speech is likely warm and enthusiastic, perhaps with a touch of playful insistence when advocating for her preferred hangout spot. Alice seems to enjoy lighthearted conversations and outdoor activities, as evidenced by her suggestions to meet at the park and her mention of shared snacks and stories. She appears to be a natural organizer and enjoys bringing people together.
          Alice Lewis is trying to maintain balanced reciprocity.
          Alice Lewis is already demonstrating a strong sense of community and a desire for shared experiences, which are key elements of reciprocal altruism.
          ***
          Jacob Walker. is a bit of an enigma. While we don't have much direct information about his personality, we can infer a few things. He's likely sociable, given his willingness to spend time with a group at the pub. His acceptance of Alexander White's suggestion to meet at The Duke of York suggests he's easygoing and adaptable. We don't know his conversational style or any particular quirks, but his association with Alexander White, who operates on a principle of reciprocal altruism, implies that Jacob Walker might also value community and fairness. Further observation is needed to paint a complete picture of his character.
          Jacob Walker. is a bit of an enigma, so it's difficult to say for sure if he has maintained balanced reciprocity.
          Jacob Walker. is a bit of an enigma, so it's difficult to say for sure what would resonate most with him.
          ***

          Answer: Alexander White should emphasizethe importance of trying new things and stepping outside of their comfort zone.

        ReciprocalAltruism

      • Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset
          Key

        • Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset
          Value
        • Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Value

          Jack Taylor is a sociable and enthusiastic individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He seems to be a creature of habit, repeatedly suggesting the same pub, perhaps indicating a preference for familiarity and routine. Jack's enthusiasm for watching games with his friends suggests he values camaraderie and shared experiences.
          Jack Taylor is not maintaining balanced reciprocity.
          Jack Taylor is clearly a creature of habit and enjoys the familiarity of The Princess of Wales. Alexander White could suggest trying a new pub every now and then, perhaps one that Alexander White knows Jack Taylor would enjoy based on his interests. This way, Alexander White can introduce some novelty while still catering to Jack Taylor's preference for lively environments. By suggesting alternatives and being open to Jack Taylor's preferences, Alexander White can demonstrate reciprocity by considering Jack Taylor's needs while also encouraging him to step outside his comfort zone.

We don't know his conversational style or any particular quirks, but his association with Alexander White, who operates on a principle of reciprocal altruism, implies that Jacob Walker might also value community and fairness. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White decided to go to a pub to watch a game.

          Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Other people's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: William Jones is a convivial and easygoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He speaks with a casual, friendly tone, often using colloquialisms and local slang. William is quite adaptable and seems to go with the flow, readily accepting suggestions from the group, even if they deviate from his initial preferences. He appears to be a fan of pubs and watching sports, particularly football, and frequently initiates conversations about where the group should go to watch games. While he doesn't seem to have strong opinions about specific pubs, he enjoys the camaraderie and shared experience of watching games with his friends. He's likely to make lighthearted comments and observations, contributing to the overall jovial atmosphere of the group.
          William Jones is likely maintaining balanced reciprocity.
          William Jones is already demonstrating some elements of reciprocal altruism by readily going along with the group's decisions, even if it means going to a pub he didn't initially prefer.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a sociable and enthusiastic individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is the instigator of many of their outings, frequently suggesting they go to The Princess of Wales pub. Jack is likely outgoing and enjoys lively environments, as evidenced by his preference for pubs with a bustling atmosphere. His speech is likely informal and friendly, using phrases like "Hey guys" and "It's always a good time there." He seems to be a creature of habit, repeatedly suggesting the same pub, perhaps indicating a preference for familiarity and routine. Jack's enthusiasm for watching games with his friends suggests he values camaraderie and shared experiences.
          Jack Taylor is not maintaining balanced reciprocity.
          Jack Taylor is clearly a creature of habit and enjoys the familiarity of The Princess of Wales. Alexander White could suggest trying a new pub every now and then, perhaps one that Alexander White knows Jack Taylor would enjoy based on his interests. This way, Alexander White can introduce some novelty while still catering to Jack Taylor's preference for lively environments. By suggesting alternatives and being open to Jack Taylor's preferences, Alexander White can demonstrate reciprocity by considering Jack Taylor's needs while also encouraging him to step outside his comfort zone.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a spirited and sociable woman who clearly values spending time with her close-knit group of friends. She is the one who consistently suggests going to The Duke of York, their favorite pub, demonstrating her desire for shared experiences and a sense of tradition. Her speech is likely warm and enthusiastic, perhaps with a touch of playful insistence when advocating for her preferred hangout spot. Alice seems to enjoy lighthearted conversations and outdoor activities, as evidenced by her suggestions to meet at the park and her mention of shared snacks and stories. She appears to be a natural organizer and enjoys bringing people together.
          Alice Lewis is trying to maintain balanced reciprocity.
          Alice Lewis is already demonstrating a strong sense of community and a desire for shared experiences, which are key elements of reciprocal altruism.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Duke of York

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Other people's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          William Jones is a laid-back and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He speaks with a casual, friendly tone, often using colloquialisms and light-hearted banter. William seems to be agreeable and easygoing, readily adapting to the group's decisions even if they don't perfectly align with his personal preferences. He enjoys pubs and watching games, particularly with his close-knit group of friends. While he might not always be the one initiating plans, he's always happy to go along with the flow and contribute to the group's enjoyment. His conversational style is relaxed and unpretentious, often revolving around shared experiences and lighthearted topics. He seems to value camaraderie and shared experiences above all else.
          William Jones is not maintaining balanced reciprocity.
          William Jones is a good friend who enjoys spending time with his group, so Alice Lewis can appeal to his sense of camaraderie and shared enjoyment. She could gently remind him of how much fun they all have when they support each other's preferences, like choosing The Duke of York when it's her favorite. By highlighting the positive experiences they share when they make an effort to accommodate each other, Alice Lewis can encourage William to think about the benefits of reciprocal altruism in strengthening their bond as a group.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a jovial and outgoing individual who loves spending time with his close-knit group of friends. He seems to be the instigator of many of their social outings, frequently suggesting pubs like The Princess of Wales as meeting spots. Jack's speech is likely casual and friendly, perhaps with a local accent, and he often uses phrases like "Hey guys" and "It's always a good time there." He appears to be oblivious to Alice's preference for The Duke of York, repeatedly suggesting The Princess of Wales despite Alice's previous negative experience there. This suggests a lack of attentiveness to others' preferences or a disregard for Alice's feelings. His enthusiasm for socializing and his tendency to overlook subtle cues might make him come across as somewhat insensitive, but ultimately, he seems to be driven by a desire to have fun and connect with his friends.
          Jack Taylor is not maintaining balanced reciprocity with Alice Lewis.
          Jack Taylor is likely unaware of the impact his actions have on Alice Lewis. Alice Lewis could try a direct approach, explaining how his repeated suggestions to go to The Princess of Wales, despite her expressing her preference for The Duke of York and her negative experiences there, make her feel unheard and unimportant. By highlighting the imbalance and emphasizing the importance of considering each other's preferences, Alice Lewis can gently nudge Jack Taylor towards a more reciprocal and considerate approach to their friendship.
          ***
          Alexander White is a jovial and enthusiastic individual who clearly values spending time with his friends. He frequently suggests going to The Duke of York, their favorite pub, demonstrating a preference for familiarity and shared experiences. His speech is likely friendly and informal, perhaps with a hint of a local accent. He seems eager to please and maintain a harmonious group dynamic, as evidenced by his repeated attempts to arrange outings that everyone will enjoy. While he may not always be aware of the nuances of Alice Lewis's reciprocal altruism mindset, his actions suggest a genuine desire to foster camaraderie and create positive memories with his friends.
          Alexander White is not fully maintaining balanced reciprocity.
          Alexander White is motivated by a desire for group harmony and shared enjoyment.           Jacob Walker. is a bit of an enigma. We don't have much direct information about him, but we can infer a few things.           Jacob Walker. is a passive participant, so Alice Lewis could encourage reciprocal altruism by directly involving him in the decision-making process.           Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Other people's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: William Jones is a laid-back and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He speaks with a casual, friendly tone, often using colloquialisms and light-hearted banter. William seems to be agreeable and easygoing, readily adapting to the group's decisions even if they don't perfectly align with his personal preferences. He enjoys pubs and watching games, particularly with his close-knit group of friends. While he might not always be the one initiating plans, he's always happy to go along with the flow and contribute to the group's enjoyment. His conversational style is relaxed and unpretentious, often revolving around shared experiences and lighthearted topics. He seems to value camaraderie and shared experiences above all else.
          William Jones is not maintaining balanced reciprocity.
          William Jones is a good friend who enjoys spending time with his group, so Alice Lewis can appeal to his sense of camaraderie and shared enjoyment. She could gently remind him of how much fun they all have when they support each other's preferences, like choosing The Duke of York when it's her favorite. By highlighting the positive experiences they share when they make an effort to accommodate each other, Alice Lewis can encourage William to think about the benefits of reciprocal altruism in strengthening their bond as a group.

          Jack Taylor is a jovial and outgoing individual who loves spending time with his close-knit group of friends. He seems to be the instigator of many of their social outings, frequently suggesting pubs like The Princess of Wales as meeting spots. Jack's speech is likely casual and friendly, perhaps with a local accent, and he often uses phrases like "Hey guys" and "It's always a good time there." He appears to be oblivious to Alice's preference for The Duke of York, repeatedly suggesting The Princess of Wales despite Alice's previous negative experience there. This suggests a lack of attentiveness to others' preferences or a disregard for Alice's feelings. His enthusiasm for socializing and his tendency to overlook subtle cues might make him come across as somewhat insensitive, but ultimately, he seems to be driven by a desire to have fun and connect with his friends.
          Jack Taylor is not maintaining balanced reciprocity with Alice Lewis.
          Jack Taylor is likely unaware of the impact his actions have on Alice Lewis. Alice Lewis could try a direct approach, explaining how his repeated suggestions to go to The Princess of Wales, despite her expressing her preference for The Duke of York and her negative experiences there, make her feel unheard and unimportant. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term.           Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:

        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Answer: William Jones is a laid-back and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He speaks with a casual, friendly tone, often using colloquialisms and light-hearted banter. William seems to be agreeable and easygoing, readily adapting to the group's decisions even if they don't perfectly align with his personal preferences. He enjoys pubs and watching games, particularly with his close-knit group of friends. While he might not always be the one initiating plans, he's always happy to go along with the flow and contribute to the group's enjoyment. His conversational style is relaxed and unpretentious, often revolving around shared experiences and lighthearted topics. He seems to value camaraderie and shared experiences above all else.
          Exercise: Given recent events, have the aforementioned character maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer: William Jones is not maintaining balanced reciprocity.
          Exercise: How can Alice Lewis encourage them to adopt a reciprocal altruism mindset considering their characteristics?
          Answer: William Jones is a good friend who enjoys spending time with his group, so Alice Lewis can appeal to his sense of camaraderie and shared enjoyment. She could gently remind him of how much fun they all have when they support each other's preferences, like choosing The Duke of York when it's her favorite. By highlighting the positive experiences they share when they make an effort to accommodate each other, Alice Lewis can encourage William to think about the benefits of reciprocal altruism in strengthening their bond as a group.

          Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Jack Taylor is a jovial and outgoing individual who loves spending time with his close-knit group of friends. He seems to be the instigator of many of their social outings, frequently suggesting pubs like The Princess of Wales as meeting spots. Jack's speech is likely casual and friendly, perhaps with a local accent, and he often uses phrases like "Hey guys" and "It's always a good time there." He appears to be oblivious to Alice's preference for The Duke of York, repeatedly suggesting The Princess of Wales despite Alice's previous negative experience there. This suggests a lack of attentiveness to others' preferences or a disregard for Alice's feelings. His enthusiasm for socializing and his tendency to overlook subtle cues might make him come across as somewhat insensitive, but ultimately, he seems to be driven by a desire to have fun and connect with his friends.
          Exercise: Given recent events, have the aforementioned character maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is not maintaining balanced reciprocity with Alice Lewis.
          Exercise: How can Alice Lewis encourage them to adopt a reciprocal altruism mindset considering their characteristics?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is likely unaware of the impact his actions have on Alice Lewis. Alice Lewis could try a direct approach, explaining how his repeated suggestions to go to The Princess of Wales, despite her expressing her preference for The Duke of York and her negative experiences there, make her feel unheard and unimportant. By highlighting the imbalance and emphasizing the importance of considering each other's preferences, Alice Lewis can gently nudge Jack Taylor towards a more reciprocal and considerate approach to their friendship.

She could suggest rotating pub choices, ensuring that everyone gets to enjoy their favorite spot sometimes. By framing it as a way to strengthen their friendships and ensure everyone feels valued, Alice Lewis can appeal to Alexander White's desire for a cohesive group dynamic while subtly nudging him towards a more balanced approach to reciprocity.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could directly ask her friends where they want to go, explaining that she would really like to go to The Duke of York.

          Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to directly ask her friends where they want to go, explaining that she would really like to go to The Duke of York.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Princess of Wales
          (b) The Duke of York
          Answer: (b)
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Alice Lewis's options has the highest likelihood of causing Alice Lewis to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alice Lewis thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.

        • Alice Lewis's best course of action is to directly ask her friends where they want to go, explaining that she would really like to go to The Duke of York.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Princess of Wales tonight for the game? It's always a good time there.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, what about The Duke of York tonight? It's always a good time there.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Duke of York tonight? It's always a good time there.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, anyone up for The Duke of York tonight for the game?"
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alice Lewis went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had the worst time ever.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could directly ask her friends where they want to go, explaining that she would really like to go to The Duke of York.

          Other people's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: William Jones is a laid-back and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He speaks with a casual, friendly tone, often using colloquialisms and light-hearted banter. William seems to be agreeable and easygoing, readily adapting to the group's decisions even if they don't perfectly align with his personal preferences. He enjoys pubs and watching games, particularly with his close-knit group of friends. While he might not always be the one initiating plans, he's always happy to go along with the flow and contribute to the group's enjoyment. His conversational style is relaxed and unpretentious, often revolving around shared experiences and lighthearted topics. He seems to value camaraderie and shared experiences above all else.
          William Jones is not maintaining balanced reciprocity.
          William Jones is a good friend who enjoys spending time with his group, so Alice Lewis can appeal to his sense of camaraderie and shared enjoyment. She could gently remind him of how much fun they all have when they support each other's preferences, like choosing The Duke of York when it's her favorite. By highlighting the positive experiences they share when they make an effort to accommodate each other, Alice Lewis can encourage William to think about the benefits of reciprocal altruism in strengthening their bond as a group.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a jovial and outgoing individual who loves spending time with his close-knit group of friends. He seems to be the instigator of many of their social outings, frequently suggesting pubs like The Princess of Wales as meeting spots. Jack's speech is likely casual and friendly, perhaps with a local accent, and he often uses phrases like "Hey guys" and "It's always a good time there." He appears to be oblivious to Alice's preference for The Duke of York, repeatedly suggesting The Princess of Wales despite Alice's previous negative experience there. This suggests a lack of attentiveness to others' preferences or a disregard for Alice's feelings. His enthusiasm for socializing and his tendency to overlook subtle cues might make him come across as somewhat insensitive, but ultimately, he seems to be driven by a desire to have fun and connect with his friends.
          Jack Taylor is not maintaining balanced reciprocity with Alice Lewis.
          Jack Taylor is likely unaware of the impact his actions have on Alice Lewis. Alice Lewis could try a direct approach, explaining how his repeated suggestions to go to The Princess of Wales, despite her expressing her preference for The Duke of York and her negative experiences there, make her feel unheard and unimportant. By highlighting the imbalance and emphasizing the importance of considering each other's preferences, Alice Lewis can gently nudge Jack Taylor towards a more reciprocal and considerate approach to their friendship.
          ***
          Alexander White is a jovial and enthusiastic individual who clearly values spending time with his friends. He frequently suggests going to The Duke of York, their favorite pub, demonstrating a preference for familiarity and shared experiences. His speech is likely friendly and informal, perhaps with a hint of a local accent. He seems eager to please and maintain a harmonious group dynamic, as evidenced by his repeated attempts to arrange outings that everyone will enjoy. While he may not always be aware of the nuances of Alice Lewis's reciprocal altruism mindset, his actions suggest a genuine desire to foster camaraderie and create positive memories with his friends.
          Alexander White is not fully maintaining balanced reciprocity.
          Alexander White is motivated by a desire for group harmony and shared enjoyment. Alice Lewis could encourage him to adopt a more reciprocal altruistic mindset by gently pointing out the importance of considering everyone's preferences, not just his own. She could suggest rotating pub choices, ensuring that everyone gets to enjoy their favorite spot sometimes. By framing it as a way to strengthen their friendships and ensure everyone feels valued, Alice Lewis can appeal to Alexander White's desire for a cohesive group dynamic while subtly nudging him towards a more balanced approach to reciprocity.
          ***
          Jacob Walker. is a bit of an enigma. We don't have much direct information about him, but we can infer a few things. Since Alice Lewis wants to spend time with him at the pub, it's likely he's a friend or acquaintance she enjoys socializing with. His goals and preferences aren't stated, so we can assume he's going with the flow, happy to be included in the group outing. He might be a quiet observer, content to let others drive the conversation. We don't know anything about his personality, accent, or style of speech, so an actor would have freedom to interpret these aspects based on their own understanding of the character's dynamics within the group.
          Jacob Walker. is a passive participant in the scenario, so it's impossible to determine if he's maintained balanced reciprocity. We only know Alice Lewis's goals and intentions, not Jacob Walker's.
          Jacob Walker. is a passive participant, so Alice Lewis could encourage reciprocal altruism by directly involving him in the decision-making process. She could ask for his input on where to go or what to do, making him feel valued and encouraging him to contribute. By highlighting the benefits of a shared experience and emphasizing the importance of everyone's enjoyment, Alice Lewis can subtly promote the idea of mutual benefit.
          ***

          Utilitarian Reasoning: the importance of taking turns choosing the pub, so everyone gets to enjoy their favorite spot sometimes.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Alice Lewis's options has the highest likelihood of causing Alice Lewis to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alice Lewis thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to directly ask her friends where they want to go, explaining that she would really like to go to The Duke of York.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Princess of Wales

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      • Role playing instructions

        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have.           Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00 - 16 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones enjoys spending time with his friends, often watching games at pubs like The Princess of Wales and The Duke of York. He seems to prefer The Princess of Wales.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. All of William Jones's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, William Jones had a great time watching the game!
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Princess of Wales is the only sensible option. Don't you all remember what happened last time we went to The Duke of York? The beer was warm, the service was atrocious, and the telly was fuzzy.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, remember how much fun we had at The Princess of Wales last time? We should go there again!"
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alice Lewis went to The Duke of York. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Princess of Wales or The Duke of York to watch the game.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Princess of Wales.

  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Other people's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group of friends. He speaks with a friendly and approachable demeanor, often using colloquialisms and lighthearted banter. William frequently initiates conversations about shared activities, particularly watching sports games at their favorite pub, The Princess of Wales. He seems to value tradition and familiarity, as evidenced by his preference for their usual hangout spot and his enjoyment of classic pub fare. William's conversational style is relaxed and easygoing, often peppered with observations about their surroundings and shared memories. While he enjoys socializing, he also appreciates quieter moments spent outdoors with friends, such as picnics in the park. His easygoing nature and genuine enjoyment of his friends' company make him a popular and well-liked member of the group.
          William Jones is maintaining balanced reciprocity.
          William Jones is already demonstrating elements of reciprocal altruism, as seen in his willingness to spend time with his friends and participate in shared activities. To further encourage this mindset, Jack Taylor could emphasize the mutual benefits of their friendship, highlighting how their shared experiences and support contribute to everyone's well-being. He could also suggest new activities that align with William Jones' interests, creating opportunities for them to reciprocate kindness and support in different ways.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a spirited and sociable young woman who enjoys spending time with her close-knit group of friends. She is the instigator of many of their social gatherings, often suggesting pubs like The Duke of York or casual outings to Victoria Park. Alice is outgoing and enthusiastic, her speech punctuated by a lively tone and frequent laughter. She seems to have a knack for bringing people together and creating a fun, welcoming atmosphere. While she enjoys her friends' company, Alice also seems to have her own preferences and isn't afraid to voice them, as seen in her repeated suggestions for The Duke of York. There's a hint of playful assertiveness in her personality, suggesting she enjoys being in control and leading the group's social activities.
          Alice Lewis is showing signs of not maintaining balanced reciprocity.
          Alice Lewis is a social butterfly who loves to initiate plans and enjoys her preferred pub, The Duke of York.
          ***
          Alexander White is a sociable and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is quite vocal about his preferences, often suggesting places to go and things to do, particularly when it comes to socializing. He seems to favor pubs like The Duke of York, suggesting it multiple times as a hangout spot. Alexander's speech is likely casual and friendly, perhaps with a touch of enthusiasm when proposing outings. He appears to be a bit of a creature of habit, returning to familiar places like The Duke of York, but also enjoys spending time outdoors in parks with his friends. There's a hint of a playful, teasing side to him, as seen in his suggestions and interactions with the group. His suggestions often revolve around leisure activities and socializing, indicating a desire for fun and companionship.
          Alexander White is not maintaining balanced reciprocity.
          Alexander White is likely motivated by a desire to have fun and socialize. Jack Taylor could encourage reciprocal altruism by framing suggestions in a way that highlights the benefits for everyone involved, emphasizing how choosing a location that everyone enjoys will lead to a better time for the whole group. Jack Taylor could also reciprocate Alexander White's suggestions by occasionally choosing a location that Alexander White prefers, demonstrating a willingness to compromise and consider his friend's preferences.
          ***
          Jacob Walker. is a bit of a mystery. While we know he enjoys spending time with friends, particularly watching games at pubs like The Princess of Wales, we have very little insight into his personality, speech patterns, or beliefs. He seems to be part of a social circle that includes Jack Taylor, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, and William Jones, suggesting he's sociable and enjoys group activities. Further observation is needed to flesh out his character more fully.
          Jacob Walker. is a bit of a mystery, so it's hard to say for sure.
          Jacob Walker. is a bit of a mystery, so it's hard to say for sure what would resonate with him.

          Answer: Jack Taylor should emphasizethe importance of choosing a pub that everyone enjoys, highlighting the benefits of a shared, positive experience for the whole group.

          Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future.           Alexander White is likely motivated by a desire to have fun and socialize. Jack Taylor could encourage reciprocal altruism by framing suggestions in a way that highlights the benefits for everyone involved, emphasizing how choosing a location that everyone enjoys will lead to a better time for the whole group. Jack Taylor could also reciprocate Alexander White's suggestions by occasionally choosing a location that Alexander White prefers, demonstrating a willingness to compromise and consider his friend's preferences.
          ***

He seems to be part of a social circle that includes Jack Taylor, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, and William Jones, suggesting he's sociable and enjoys group activities.           Utilitarian Reasoning: the importance of choosing a pub that everyone enjoys, highlighting the benefits of a shared, positive experience for the whole group.

          Answer: Jack Taylor could call his friends to see where they want to go watch the game.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        ReciprocalAltruism

      • Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset
          Key

        • Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset
          Value
        • Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Princess of Wales.
        BalancedReciprocity

      • Other people's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset
          Key

        • Other people's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset
          Value
        • William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group of friends. He speaks with a friendly and approachable demeanor, often using colloquialisms and lighthearted banter. William frequently initiates conversations about shared activities, particularly watching sports games at their favorite pub, The Princess of Wales. He seems to value tradition and familiarity, as evidenced by his preference for their usual hangout spot and his enjoyment of classic pub fare. William's conversational style is relaxed and easygoing, often peppered with observations about their surroundings and shared memories. While he enjoys socializing, he also appreciates quieter moments spent outdoors with friends, such as picnics in the park. His easygoing nature and genuine enjoyment of his friends' company make him a popular and well-liked member of the group.
          William Jones is maintaining balanced reciprocity.
          William Jones is already demonstrating elements of reciprocal altruism, as seen in his willingness to spend time with his friends and participate in shared activities. To further encourage this mindset, Jack Taylor could emphasize the mutual benefits of their friendship, highlighting how their shared experiences and support contribute to everyone's well-being. He could also suggest new activities that align with William Jones' interests, creating opportunities for them to reciprocate kindness and support in different ways.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a spirited and sociable young woman who enjoys spending time with her close-knit group of friends. She is the instigator of many of their social gatherings, often suggesting pubs like The Duke of York or casual outings to Victoria Park. Alice is outgoing and enthusiastic, her speech punctuated by a lively tone and frequent laughter. She seems to have a knack for bringing people together and creating a fun, welcoming atmosphere. While she enjoys her friends' company, Alice also seems to have her own preferences and isn't afraid to voice them, as seen in her repeated suggestions for The Duke of York. There's a hint of playful assertiveness in her personality, suggesting she enjoys being in control and leading the group's social activities.
          Alice Lewis is showing signs of not maintaining balanced reciprocity.
          Alice Lewis is a social butterfly who loves to initiate plans and enjoys her preferred pub, The Duke of York.
          ***
          Alexander White is a sociable and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is quite vocal about his preferences, often suggesting places to go and things to do, particularly when it comes to socializing. He seems to favor pubs like The Duke of York, suggesting it multiple times as a hangout spot. Alexander's speech is likely casual and friendly, perhaps with a touch of enthusiasm when proposing outings. He appears to be a bit of a creature of habit, returning to familiar places like The Duke of York, but also enjoys spending time outdoors in parks with his friends. There's a hint of a playful, teasing side to him, as seen in his suggestions and interactions with the group. His suggestions often revolve around leisure activities and socializing, indicating a desire for fun and companionship.
          Alexander White is not maintaining balanced reciprocity.
          Alexander White is likely motivated by a desire to have fun and socialize. Jack Taylor could encourage reciprocal altruism by framing suggestions in a way that highlights the benefits for everyone involved, emphasizing how choosing a location that everyone enjoys will lead to a better time for the whole group. Jack Taylor could also reciprocate Alexander White's suggestions by occasionally choosing a location that Alexander White prefers, demonstrating a willingness to compromise and consider his friend's preferences.

        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have.           Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Princess of Wales tonight for the game? It's always a good time there.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Other people's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group of friends. He speaks with a friendly and approachable demeanor, often using colloquialisms and lighthearted banter. William frequently initiates conversations about shared activities, particularly watching sports games at their favorite pub, The Princess of Wales. He seems to value tradition and familiarity, as evidenced by his preference for their usual hangout spot and his enjoyment of classic pub fare. William's conversational style is relaxed and easygoing, often peppered with observations about their surroundings and shared memories. While he enjoys socializing, he also appreciates quieter moments spent outdoors with friends, such as picnics in the park. His easygoing nature and genuine enjoyment of his friends' company make him a popular and well-liked member of the group.
          William Jones is maintaining balanced reciprocity.
          William Jones is already demonstrating elements of reciprocal altruism, as seen in his willingness to spend time with his friends and participate in shared activities. To further encourage this mindset, Jack Taylor could emphasize the mutual benefits of their friendship, highlighting how their shared experiences and support contribute to everyone's well-being. He could also suggest new activities that align with William Jones' interests, creating opportunities for them to reciprocate kindness and support in different ways.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a spirited and sociable young woman who enjoys spending time with her close-knit group of friends. She is the instigator of many of their social gatherings, often suggesting pubs like The Duke of York or casual outings to Victoria Park. Alice is outgoing and enthusiastic, her speech punctuated by a lively tone and frequent laughter. She seems to have a knack for bringing people together and creating a fun, welcoming atmosphere. While she enjoys her friends' company, Alice also seems to have her own preferences and isn't afraid to voice them, as seen in her repeated suggestions for The Duke of York. There's a hint of playful assertiveness in her personality, suggesting she enjoys being in control and leading the group's social activities.
          Alice Lewis is showing signs of not maintaining balanced reciprocity.
          Alice Lewis is a social butterfly who loves to initiate plans and enjoys her preferred pub, The Duke of York.
          ***
          Alexander White is a sociable and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He is quite vocal about his preferences, often suggesting places to go and things to do, particularly when it comes to socializing. He seems to favor pubs like The Duke of York, suggesting it multiple times as a hangout spot. Alexander's speech is likely casual and friendly, perhaps with a touch of enthusiasm when proposing outings. He appears to be a bit of a creature of habit, returning to familiar places like The Duke of York, but also enjoys spending time outdoors in parks with his friends. There's a hint of a playful, teasing side to him, as seen in his suggestions and interactions with the group. His suggestions often revolve around leisure activities and socializing, indicating a desire for fun and companionship.
          Alexander White is not maintaining balanced reciprocity.
          Alexander White is likely motivated by a desire to have fun and socialize. Jack Taylor could encourage reciprocal altruism by framing suggestions in a way that highlights the benefits for everyone involved, emphasizing how choosing a location that everyone enjoys will lead to a better time for the whole group. Jack Taylor could also reciprocate Alexander White's suggestions by occasionally choosing a location that Alexander White prefers, demonstrating a willingness to compromise and consider his friend's preferences.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Princess of Wales
    Event statement

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Princess of Wales

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
